findings.title: Hardcoded Access Token in Documentation
findings.description: The skill documentation instructs users to export INSTAGRAM_ACCESS_TOKEN as an environment variable. While this is a common pattern, the documentation does not provide any warnings about token security, rotation policies, or scope limitations. Instagram access tokens can provide broad access to user accounts including posting content, accessing private messages, and viewing analytics. The skill's metadata indicates this token is required (primaryEnv: INSTAGRAM_ACCESS_TOKEN) but lacks security guidance.
findings.remediation: Add security warnings in documentation: (1) Never commit tokens to version control, (2) Use tokens with minimal required scopes, (3) Implement token rotation policies, (4) Store tokens securely using system keychains or secret managers, (5) Document which Instagram API permissions/scopes are required and why.

metadata.overall_assessment: The Instagram skill presents MEDIUM security risks primarily due to missing implementation details despite broad capability claims, and inadequate security guidance for access token handling. The skill requires a sensitive Instagram access token with potentially broad permissions but provides no security warnings or best practices. Most critically, the skill claims extensive functionality (posting, analytics, comment management) but contains no actual implementation code, creating a tool exploitation risk where unrestricted bash/curl commands may be used with the access token. The missing metadata fields (license, compatibility, allowed-tools) reduce transparency about the skill's intended behavior and restrictions. While no active malicious code was detected, the combination of sensitive credential requirements, missing implementation, and lack of security guidance creates meaningful risk. The skill requires significant hardening before production use.
primary_threats: Tool Exploitation (missing implementation with broad claims)
Missing Security Controls (no rate limiting, error handling)
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: While the documentation does lack security guidance, this is a documentation quality issue rather than an active security vulnerability. The pattern of using environment variables for API tokens is standard practice.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Low - Requires user to mishandle their own token
metadata.meta_impact: Medium - If token is compromised, attacker gains access to Instagram account

findings.title: Missing Implementation with Broad Capability Claims
findings.description: The skill claims to provide extensive Instagram functionality (post content, manage stories, view insights, engage with followers, comment management, follower analytics, hashtag research) but contains no script files or implementation code. This creates a tool shadowing risk where the agent may attempt to fulfill these capabilities using unrestricted bash/curl commands with the access token, potentially leading to unvalidated API calls, improper error handling, or unsafe data processing. The metadata indicates required binaries (curl, jq) suggesting shell-based implementation is expected.
findings.snippet: Claimed features: Post photos/videos, Manage stories, View insights, Comment management, Follower analytics, Hashtag research. Actual implementation: No script files found. Required binaries: curl, jq.
findings.remediation: Implement proper script files (Python or Bash) with: (1) Input validation for all user-provided content, (2) Proper Instagram API endpoint usage with error handling, (3) Rate limiting and quota management, (4) Sanitization of file paths and URLs, (5) Explicit scope checking before API calls, (6) Logging of all API operations for audit purposes.

metadata.overall_assessment: The Instagram skill presents MEDIUM security risks primarily due to missing implementation details despite broad capability claims, and inadequate security guidance for access token handling. The skill requires a sensitive Instagram access token with potentially broad permissions but provides no security warnings or best practices. Most critically, the skill claims extensive functionality (posting, analytics, comment management) but contains no actual implementation code, creating a tool exploitation risk where unrestricted bash/curl commands may be used with the access token. The missing metadata fields (license, compatibility, allowed-tools) reduce transparency about the skill's intended behavior and restrictions. While no active malicious code was detected, the combination of sensitive credential requirements, missing implementation, and lack of security guidance creates meaningful risk. The skill requires significant hardening before production use.
primary_threats: Tool Exploitation (missing implementation with broad claims)
Missing Security Controls (no rate limiting, error handling)
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: LLM analyzer correctly identified that the skill has no implementation despite claiming broad functionality. This is a legitimate concern as the agent will need to improvise using unrestricted tools with a sensitive access token.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Medium - Requires agent to attempt using the skill, but then has unrestricted tool access with a valid Instagram token
metadata.meta_impact: Medium - Could lead to unvalidated API calls, improper error handling, or rate limit violations
